captions.text: Welcome to 240SX Episode 3!
Finally we're back.

It's been a long time coming we've been
busy with things like testing the
Porsche 918 and McLaren P1,

but now we're back to what's important:
a 21-year-old Nissan.

Seriously, we've been dying to work on
this car for a long time.

It's been a while so let's go over what
we did.
We tested it, drifted it, and then it broke.

With it running on three cylinders we
decided of course

to work on the wheels, tires, and brakes.
It's what you do right?

A 5 lug hub conversion allowed us to
install 17-inch Rays Gram lights

which we wrapped with massive BF
Goodrich tires.

And underneath that went big, awesome
Brembos up front.

The cost of those breaks made a lot of
people angry as they

easily exceeded the value of the car. If
you're one of those people
you should probably stop watching now.

So this week we're gonna finish what we
started last year which is

get the 240SX set up for stopping and
handling before we add

what'll probably end up being way too
much horsepower. Mark Lenardon's back with
his magical

wink of magic. Mark knows what he's doing
so

all you guys in the forums who complain
about our build... You can blame me.

But anyway let's go over the parts. We
have
coilovers from KW they're Clubsports. We also have
Enjuku Isis their full suspension package. Also we have a 300ZX

set of rear brakes. Brembo replacement
rotors for those breaks.

And as well as these fine Recaro seats. On
the bodywork side we overnighted from
Japan

these fenders from Origin and they'll be
nice because they'll make

actually wide bodies are just cool that's
why the real reason why.

Wide bodies are just cool. And we have 3
inches of front tire sticking out. Which is not
a bad thing.

First up: suspension. The blue Tucecos
are a decent replacement budget shock

but we wanted something better a lot
better and KW Clubsports are a vast
improvement in pretty much

every way. KW positions these coilovers
as a solution for cars prepped for
street and track use.

They're easy to install and look great
once in place. So I just put in the KW
Clubsport

coil over on this side and took out the old
strut it was an old Toceco
and right off the bat it saves about 20 pounds. That old Toceco was
really heavy. One of the big things that's awesome about KW coilovers
is that these are completely rebuildable and you can re-valve them to any setting
you like.

We're also replacing the tension rods up
front,

the rear toe link's upper control arms, and
traction links with a kit from
Isis and Enjuku racing. Easy on the budget

these links are tough and adjustable so
we'll be able to tailor castor, toe, and
camber.

Enjuku backs them strongly and uses them
on the company's drift car.

Installation is simple unbolt the stock
parts and bolt in the new ones.

It's a good idea to measure the stock
arms for length before installing the
new ones

as it'll save you some alignment work.
We're just about finished with the front
end of the car
we have the KW Clubsports on the tension rods in

and the nice thing is is all the colors
match which is very important

when it comes to suspension design and
tuning. Well we've basically finished
disassembling

the rear end of the 240SX. It's the
second time we've done it and we're getting
pretty good at it.
If we're lucky we may get to disassemble it a third time maybe a fourth time depending
on how things go with the build.

I'm holding in my hand an upper control
arm from Isis / Enjuku,
and it replaces this guy this upper control arm. We're also replacing

the traction rod and the toe control links
with

components like these. These are
adjustable, they're durable,
they're strong, that's why we're using them. We've already replaced the 240SX brakes with

300ZX brakes which is nice we've
actually replaced the

hubs themselves we've got a new dust
shield on,

and we've been able to keep the 240SX
knuckle which is nice cuz the suspension
will bolt right up to that.
If you ever find yourself
underneath a 20-year-old Nissan 240SX
you're gonna find everything's corroded all the bolts are

screwed up stripped because it's
probably been stolen like this one was
and put together
kinda not so great. Not stolen by us.
What? Not stolen by us. Not stolen by us that's a very important thing to

point out. If you find yourself in this
position,

and need to take apart the rear end start
with the lower control arm.

It's easier. What's really sweet about these
is that
each side is opposite threads. One is regular one is reversed.

But just to adjust toe even at this point
right now so we can eyeball it
you can just pretty much twist it and make on the fly stuff real easy.
And you lock it with that nut? Yes you just lock it with each hex nut and same thing with the
upper control arm and traction rod the same thing with the front and the tension rods and stuff.
And it makes it super easy. For the rear brakes
we turn to the second generation 300ZX. It's a common upgrade for 240SX's.

We assemble the replacement kit
combining used parts OE hardware
from Nissan online's parts store
and for pads we went to Project Mu. Despite the fact you're changing the
entire rear braking system

it's largely a simple bolt-on process.
I'm a huge advocate for functional
interiors and fast cars.

The easier it is to use the pedals,
shifter, and wheel

the faster you can go. Problem is getting
decent seats that fit into the S13 chassis
is a pain.

There isn't much headroom and most side
bolsters poke out past the door.
Bulges in the floor pan create a fitting problem too.

We got a pair of beautiful and
comfortable Recaro pole positions,

which we were told would fit low melt
buddy club seat rails.

That's almost true. In order to fit the
stock mounting holes the seats have to

be at the highest position on the
bracket

which leads to a terrible seating
position. In order to mount the seats
properly
we had to weld a tab to one of the brackets on the rail. Doing so allowed us
to put the seat at the perfect height

giving us a great seating position. With
all the important stuff bolted together

we thought it wise to look at the
fenders with the suspension slightly
lower

we were just at maybe a little bit
beyond the max tire size the wheel wells
would take.

Just about everything cleared except for
the fenders and quarter panels.

Neither of those are particularly
important so we took off the fronts and cut out
the rears.

We also trimmed out more non-essential
parts from the front wheel wells and
relocated the wiring harness.

The fronts replace the stock units and
the rears bolt over the existing
quarter panel.

If you want to end up with a really nice
looking wide body kit

on your car you go to a professional, you
spend good money, and you wait till it's
done.

If you just care about tire clearance
you cut out the quarter panel, you rib it
on your overs,

and call it a day because there's more
important things to do.

When we left off last year the 240 was
running like a Subaru

because it was on three cylinders and
we weren't really sure what was up and we

didn't really look at it too hard, but once we
did
we found out that the problem was this guy: bad fuel injector.

We checked the cylinders and we found
out it was number four that wasn't
firing.
Mark checked. Cylinder was dry so no fuel was going there that means either the
injector's bad or the ECU's bad. Yep.
Injector driver or injector itself. So next we

moved injectors around and when we did
that we were able to move the problem

around so that meant it was definitely
the injector.

Trip to Auto Zone this guy and now
we're going to go purring
like a kitten.
So now you're probably wondering with

these brakes, with the suspension, with
the tires, with the body work
why we've done all this. Yeah why don't we tell them?

Well that's because of what's in this
crate.

In here is a 430 horsepower LS3 from
Chevy performance parts it's an E-Rod
motor

so it's smog legal. We also have a T-56
Super Magnum 6-speed manual

and at the end of this year it's all going
inside the car. Looking like it just
emerged from the junkyard

we were eager to see how much of a
difference the new parts made.

Never mind that we hadn't checked
the alignment or anything

We just went to the test track to see what
would happen it's a lesson we learned from
our friends at Roadkill.
Despite installing heavier and stronger parts,

bigger wheels, and brakes we were
surprised that the Nissan

only gained about 33 pounds. That gain
was worth it.
Our best stop from 60 miles an hour dropped to 115 feet,
which is a huge improvement from the 157 feet it took it when we first
got the car.

We noticed the rear brakes locked up
before the fronts

showing that we're leaving some
performance on the table. We were feeling pretty
good about the braking performance,
but then we went over to the handling track. There the 240SX
was simply hilarious. It's the definition of a momentum car.

The 118 rear wheel horsepower means it
is very fast

but it's so light and grippy you don't really
have to stop for

corners. And even with those big sticky
tires and no power

the chassis was still flexible enough to
drift.
Its best lap at 25.4 seconds

matches what we've recorded from the
Focus ST and Subaru WRX.

And it's worth repeating this thing
dynoed at a 118 horsepower.
It's making up all that time in the corners

as evident by its 1.01 G-average
around the skid pad.
Over 1G without tuning!
Hey camera! How was that? It dead?
Not it's still rolling.

title: 1993 Nissan 240SX - Part 3: Making it Stick and Stop! - Ignition Ep. 110

comments.text:
You said the car only made 118 rear-wheel hp when you tested it after the 
suspension mods but that was on only 3 cylinders due to the bad injector. 
Should be higher unless you tested it before you replaced the injector. 
Also what happened to the nice, big, black, Brembo brake calipers from Part 
2 of this series?  Why did you go with the 300Z brakes. I guess it's 
representative of common mods done to this car. Love the videos and the 
build.  Keep up the good work.﻿

comments.text:
The LS is a good engine, but it's about as exciting as an SR swap. Both are 
solid platforms, I myself have an SR, ha ha. My biggest issue with this 
"build", is combination of quality parts (Rays wheels, KW coils, etc) with 
cheap half-assed chinese/taiwanese crap (aka ISIS). And there are tons of 
better/cheaper brake options out there, but I guess you have to go with the 
sponsors. It's still not bad for a publication with no long term 240SX 
enthusiast experience.﻿
